Expectation1: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation1: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They face a serious situation that directly tests their commitment to Christian morals
Story:
I was sweeping up stray hair when the bell chimed and the bride-to-be swept in, her entourage trailing behind, all nerves and hurried whispers. I smiled, welcoming them, trying to ease their tension. As a hairdresser, it’s my job to make clients feel at home, especially on a day as important as this. I offered them tea, complimented the bride’s dress, and listened to their anxious chatter about the tight schedule. 

But then, as I started on the bride’s hair, one of her friends pulled me aside. She quietly asked if I could help cover up a tattoo on the bride’s neck—a symbol from a wild night, something the bride’s conservative family mustn’t see. She offered extra cash, urging me to keep it secret. 

My hands trembled. As a Christian, honesty and integrity are core to who I am. I felt the weight of their expectation to help, to be discreet, to make the day perfect. But I also felt the pull of my faith, the call to truthfulness and not to aid in deception. My heart pounded as I stood between my scissors and my conscience, unsure which role I could bear to disappoint.
